title: AMT Lightning pistol
text:
The AMT Lightning pistol is a <a href="semi-automatic%20pistol">semi-automatic pistol</a> chambered for <a href=".22%20Long%20Rifle">.22 Long Rifle</a> which was manufactured by <a href="Arcadia%20Machine%20%26amp%3B%20Tool">Arcadia Machine & Tool</a> (AMT) of <a href="Covina%2C%20California">Covina, California</a> during the 1980s and early 1990s.
The pistol was an unlicensed, stainless steel clone of the <a href="Ruger%20Mark%20II">Ruger Mark II</a> pistol, that was updated from the Ruger, by the addition of target sights, target trigger, and Pachmayr target grips as standard items. The Lightning had the receiver grooved for <a href="scope%20mount">scope mount</a>ing and the trigger guard was designed to allow a two hand hold. At the time of the Lightning pistol's introduction, stainless steel Ruger Mk series pistols were rare. The Lightning pistol, along with the <a href="AMT%20Lightning%2025/22">AMT Lightning 25/22</a> rifle, prompted a successful <a href="trademark%20infringement">trademark infringement</a> lawsuit by <a href="Ruger">Ruger</a> that forced AMT to discontinue the model line.
